awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Rigorous Integration of Decision Procedures and Numerical Algorithms for the Formal Verification of Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project establishes a new framework for the formal verification of cyber-physical systems. The framework combines the power of logical decision engines and scalable numerical methods to perform safety verification of general nonlinear hybrid systems. The key difficulty with formal verification of hybrid systems is that all scalable modern verification techniques rely heavily on the use of powerful decision procedures. For hybrid systems, one needs to reason about logic formulas over the real numbers with nonlinear functions, which has been regarded as an intractable problem. The project proposes new directions for tackling the core decision problems, with the combined power of logical and numerical algorithms. The research directly leads to the development of practical tools that will push the frontier of verification of realistic cyber-physical systems to a brand new level.

This project aims at fundamental research of problems that stand at the core of the design, analysis, and implementation of reliable cyber-physical systems. It combines techniques from logic, numerical analysis, and automated reasoning, and will produce a unifying methodology that is powerful to address main challenges in this field. The techniques developed in this project will significantly enhance the complexity and reliability of the next generations of cyber-physical systems.

 Cyber-physical systems are ubiquitous in safety-critical applications as diverse as aerospace, automotive, civil infrastructure, energy, manufacturing, and healthcare. Malfunctioning cyber-physical systems can have catastrophic economic and societal consequences. This project will have a broad range of impact in these areas. 
This research aims to significantly enhance the management of complexity and reliability of the next generations of cyber-physical systems, and will broadly impact all the application areas.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of the project is the development of several algorithms and tools for the analysis and safety proof of hybrid systems and their applications in several domains from self-driving cars to biological questions.  Among the tools are the three interconnected systems dReach, dReal, and SReach.
Intellectual Merit.
The open-source tool dReach encodes reachability problems of hybrid systems to first-order formulas over real numbers.  These formulas are then solved by the delta decision procedures in dReal.  In this way, dReach is able to handle a wide range of highly nonlinear hybrid systems. It has scaled well on various realistic models from biomedical to robotics applications.
The SReach system is the outcome of the study of probabilistic bounded reachability problems for two classes of models of stochastic hybrid systems. The first one is nonlinear hybrid automata with parametric uncertainty. The second one is probabilistic hybrid automata with additional randomness for both transition probabilities and variable resets. SReach has been applied to three representative biological models and additional benchmarks for nonlinear hybrid systems with multiple probabilistic system parameters.
We have designed a novel simplex architecture for hybrid systems using so?called barrier certificates. Barrier certificates are Lyapunov?like proofs of safety are used to identify a recoverable region when a safety violation of a hybrid system is imminent. Example hybrid systems where this applies are a water tank pump and a controller for a car designed to obey stop signs.
We also introduced LRT, a new Lagrangian?based ReachTube computation algorithm to approximate the reachable states of a nonlinear dynamical system. It uses the Cauchy?Green stretching factor to overapproximate the gradient of the solution flows. Preliminary experiments show that LRT compares favorably with other tools like CAPD and Flow*.
Broader Impacts.
Our automated reasoning tool dReal has been successfully adopted by the Toyota Research Institute for verifying core planning algorithms in autonomous driving systems. A student whose PhD work has been funded by the project recently started working as a researcher at the Toyota institute to lead the integration of dReal into their development platform for autonomous driving and home robotics.  We have introduced new techniques from software verification to the domain of hybrid systems, including interpolant?guided reasoning and compositional reasoning. Such techniques are crucial for scaling up verification.  Our solver dReal has also been used in finding cyber?physical security exploits in electric power grids.
As another application of our approaches, we used our methodologies to study the efficacy of hormone therapy for prostate cancer. Recent clinical studies suggest that the efficacy of hormone therapy depends on the characteristics of individual patients. We develop a computational framework for identifying patient?specific androgen ablation therapy schedules for postponing the potential cancer relapse.  The results show that our methods are promising and may lead to a prognostic tool for prostate cancer therapy.  dReal has also been used to compute personalized therapies for psoriasis that will soon enter clinical trial at a hospital in Newcastle, UK.
